items.title: SUVs
items.content_html:
The Guardian reports on a group of activists called the Tyre Extinguishers whose MO is letting down the tyres of SUVs. This activism is thought to be in response to the incident in London where a Land Rover had crashed through a school fence and killed two eight-year-old girls. I live in an inner city area on a road of terraced and semi-detached houses cut in time when far fewer people owned cars. Thus it’s double-parked. There is barely room for a Land Rover to fit through. Indeed, there is no need for Land Rover on my street but there are a fair few people that own them on my street.

I get it: it’s keeping up with the Joneses. That and a feeling of safety. As the parent of a small girl, I don’t like them. I didn’t bother before but I don’t like them now. But I get why other parents buy them for that semblance of safety when they are inside the car. On our walks to school, I’ve noticed a couple of local childminders I know use them probably for that very reason. Yet as the article points out:

The problem with building cars for the protection of those within them, however, is that it tends to have a deleterious effect on the protection of those without… [That] has led to an escalation, a sort of arms race, in which everyone buys ever larger and heavier cars to protect themselves from all the other larger and heavier cars… The heavily encased, elevated position of the SUV driver creates a ‘sensation of safety’ that means they ‘will tend to “export” their risk, putting other road users at greater risk‘.

According to one American study, published in the Journal of Safety Research, children are eight times more likely to die when struck by an SUV compared with an average passenger car. Obviously, no sane consumer would select a car on that particular basis… People are more interested in protecting their own children. But according to some statistics, it appears that even this instinct may have been misleadingly exploited. In his 2002 book High and Mighty, Keith Bradsher found that occupant death rate was 6% higher in SUVs than in conventional cars, and 8% in the biggest ones.

For all their inner-city impracticality, at least the ‘urban’ Land Rovers and other smaller SUVs have a bonnet gradient that just about gives the driver enough vision to see close enough in front of them. Like say Transit vans. I take more issue with the huge US imports. The Ford Ranger-esque utes. There is a Dodge pickup truck parked on my road. I am 5 feet 6. The height of the vehicle to the bonnet, which is not sloped, is taller than me. It’s not stopping for anything under 4 foot. The choice of the selfish.

items.title: We (possibly) don’t need another Twitter, part 2
items.content_html:
This is a follow up from We (possibly) don’t need another Twitter. 10 weeks or so down the line two things appear clear: a) Twitter’s user base is not dying to the degree we thought it might, and b) Threads and LinkedIn are taking the bulk of those making the jump. I imagine the main reason for this is critical mass. Mastodon and Bluesky do not have it. They are not busy enough, there are not enough of your peers there, and in the case of Mastodon, the signing-up process is too complex for the average user. If you are largely shouting into an echo chamber, you may as well start a blog.

Writing for The Thesis Whisperer, Zeb Larson laments the situation:

As I built new networks on Mastodon, my old community of Twitterstorians showed up – but critically, they didn’t stick around. Other Mastodon users would ask me, ‘why? Why did they go back to Twitter?’… the alternatives are too small.

Mastodon is a network I really like, but it has fewer than two million daily users; moreover, the experience of picking a server seems to have turned a number of people off. Bluesky is still in Beta and similarly has fewer than two million accounts. Features for the former are fiddly; features for the latter are still in progress. Threads is a terrible vehicle for discussing news, and academics really like being able to discuss the news. LinkedIn is popular for the alt-ac crowd, but by and large it’s not being used by those within academia. Twitter’s been a community for people and a source of support, so they’re not likely to abandon it unless their networks have mostly migrated…

If only some people leave, you can’t recreate the ecosystem very effectively.

I don’t recognise LinkedIn as the ‘alt-ac’ choice more it being the genuine alternative for academics. But it just isn’t the same. The mechanics aren’t the same. It’s not as live. It’s not as spontaneous (arguably a good thing). Posts are crafted in a certain way to the point that browsing for longer than a couple of minutes becomes irksome. Richard Littler feels similar with a remark that is a strong contender for comment of the year:

Everyone is now a business coach/mentor/consultant espousing platitudes copied & pasted from every other consultant. Like a self-perpetuating ouroboros of nonsense.

Joseph A adds:

I reluctantly signed up earlier this year, having been told that I’d find lots of useful stuff for work there. It feels like I’ve connected a fire hydrant of Barry Homeowner slurry to my email inbox.

The one positive thing you can say about LinkedIn is that it is positive. But can you be too positive?

items.title: Wegbier
items.content_html:
‘It’s normal in Berlin to drink a bottle of beer as you wander between pubs… or wander anywhere, for that matter,’ write Boak & Bailey. Essentially, this is a wegbier—a beer you consume while walking around or getting from one place to another. Several brands market their beers specifically as wegbiers for this purpose.

‘Back home, people look askance if you‘re carrying an open bottle of beer in the street… In Berlin, on Saturday night, they look askance if you’re not.’

And it’s not just for those off work:

‘One weekday afternoon we watched a smartly-dressed thirty-something couple escorting their small children along the street. Both parents were carrying open bottles of lager as casually as someone in Britain might carry a to-go cappuccino.’

Remarkable, and the culture is not limited to Berliners either, though perhaps not as accepted or widespread as Berlin. In their footnotes (£), Boak and Bailey mentioned the earliest they noticed a wegbier supped was prior to 10am. Many chose Desperado as their wegbier—not a light choice by any means!—but iced tea appeared to be a popular substitute for an alcoholic beverage.

items.title: What makes a professional in sport?
items.content_html:
York Valkyrie, York RLFC’s women’s team, is the first club outside of Australia and New Zealand to sign several of their players to salaried contracts. It’s a significant step forward for the game and it also makes sense for York too, in that they can establish their women’s team as one of, if not the, elite club in the women’s competition.

York’s headline is ‘Valkyrie make history by signing professional contracts’. The detail: ‘The contracts are made up of base salaries, a range of performance-related bonuses and also include maternity leave support and NRLW player options.’ (The NRLW being the premier competition in Australia and New Zealand which is a further level in terms of salary and benefits.)

This isn’t the beginning of women being paid to play rugby league—York was also the first club, along with Leeds Rhinos, to introduce winning and losing pay—so York’s definition of a ‘professional’ here is not necessarily as a full-time employee but a salaried one nonetheless.

Now, if we were to rewind 130 years, being paid any amount of money or even payment in kind would have labelled you as a professional. Yet today, we tend to demarcate those who earn their full wage from playing sport as a professional from those earning a portion of their income from playing sport as semi-professional. The wages earned by semi-professionals, such as non-league footballers, can be significant sums of money; some above the national minimum wage.

‘Semi-professional’ is such a flimsy, non-term though. Let’s say you have two jobs and one of them is as a consultant contracted to ten hours a week. You are not half the consultant of your peers working 40 hours a week. Therefore, you are not a semi-professional consultant but a part-time professional consultant. Using this logic, York RLFC’s women players are as professional now as they were last year and as they will be when full-time contracts are offered. But in sport, the difference between it being your part-time pursuit and your full-time job is significant, and that alone will probably see the ‘semi-pro’ tag hanging on for some time. Urgh.

items.title: 23 and Me
items.content_html:
Last year I participated in a research project which involved taking a 23andMe DNA test. In return for a free test, I attended a couple of interviews with academic colleagues who asked me about my experience and my take on the moralities of the potential use cases of DNA profiling. I had two key motives for taking the test. Familial history, one’s heritage, I find interesting in general. But also I had not long since discovered that I have myocardial bridging—a congenital heart defect, generally considered to be benign, where my left anterior descending artery at some point goes into the myocardium (my heart muscle itself) for a stretch before remerging—so I was quite keen to find if were any other health markers of concern within my genetic code.

The results are fascinating really, one in particular being my heritage. I fully expected my DNA lineage to be 100% British and Irish. It wasn’t. It was 99% British and Irish with 1% showing as Spanish and Portuguese. I looked for the 1% margin of error disclaimer, but according to 23andMe, it is ‘most likely’ that one of my ancestors, born sometime between 1710 and 1830, was 100% Spanish or Portuguese. That certainly piqued my interest, error margin or not (marketing gimmick, perhaps?). Watch this space on that discovery.

The health markers, while also interesting, are more trivial tidbits. ~2% of my ancestral DNA is neanderthal, which may mean I have a less-than-average sense of direction. I have a genetic marker indicating that if I eat asparagus, my pee is likely to smell afterwards (and it does). There’s a confirmation bias, like going to see a medium I suppose, where you latch on to the predictions that you see as being true. ‘You are more likely to be a sprinter than a long-distance runner.’ YES! I knew it… More concerning: I have one of the genetic markers linked to the development of Alzheimer’s. However, the raised risk here appears to be minuscule as if to be a coin toss, and these health statements are littered with coin tosses. ‘You have a 53% likelihood of having a hairy back,’ for example.

The most concerning development, however, is 23andMe’s recent data breach. This wasn’t a hack of the company. It was a hack of hundreds of individuals’ accounts with weak or repeated-use passwords. These hundreds of people are linked to thousands of others through their DNA matches. 23andMe informed me that whilst my account was not hacked, I was linked to the DNA profile of an account that was. Therefore, my DNA profile was open to leverage by the hackers. As Ignacio Cofone explains:

Hackers are offering the assembled genetic information for sale, with lists that include thousands of people. Hackers reportedly assembled and put up for sale lists of people with Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry. Individuals on the list now face increased risk of discrimination or harassment, as leaked data includes names and location. Other information from the company would allow them to do the same for people with a propensity for Type 2 diabetes, Parkinson’s disease or dementia — all of which 23andMe measures — putting them at risk of other harms, from raised insurance premiums to employment discrimination.

> Hackers are offering the assembled genetic information for sale, with lists that include thousands of people. Hackers reportedly assembled and put up for sale lists of people with Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry. Individuals on the list now face increased risk of discrimination or harassment, as leaked data includes names and location. Other information from the company would allow them to do the same for people with a propensity for Type 2 diabetes, Parkinson’s disease or dementia — all of which 23andMe measures — putting them at risk of other harms, from raised insurance premiums to employment discrimination.

items.title: Ultra-processed food
items.content_html:
Ultra-processed foods or UPFs are the new ciggies. I have Tim Spector’s recent book regarding these on my never-decreasing pile, but Chris Van Tulleken also has his own publication. There is a litany of issues arising from consuming UPFs and they are in a lot of food products that many of us would class as staples. As Van Tulleken explains in this Royal Institution lecture they’ve been snook into our snacks without our consent and without the dangers of consuming them made clear. Why? Because they are addictive, cheap fillers and preserve dry, non-foods, making them appear and taste like actual food.

You don’t have to know much about UPFs to realise that the route to avoiding them is to consume a diet of whole foods with few but proper organic ingredients. But what I like about Van Tulleken’s talk here is that while he acknowledges this, he also understands that whole foods are expensive to buy and have a short shelf-life, requiring forward planning to cook before they go off. This forces the poor and the time-poor into making poor choices.

The warning system for consumers is also flawed and misleading. This system being the RAG status of calories, sugar and fat levels contained within food products. Diet Coke, as Van Tulleken notes, is one of the healthiest products you could consume based on the RAG rating. Yet it is full of chemicals that mess with your body’s internals.

Not only that, the whole food life is not cool, it’s boring. They aren’t found in the enticing packets on the shelves; they aren’t pushed in the fun adverts on TV. There’s only so much you can control what your children see, eat or indeed want to eat. Van Tulleken shows his young daughter wolfing down UPF-laden chocolate cereal, a fact of life rather than to his chagrin. I know, occasionally it has to be a case of ceding to your kids so at least they eat something before school rather than nothing.

A major culprit is the targeted and effective branding and advertising. Some countries force these brands to display warning signs on their packaging and remove their colourful mascots. It may need to go further: blank, bleak packaging with warning messages and photos. Ultra-processed foods are the new ciggies.

items.title: iMessage on a dumbphone
items.content_html:
The latest video from the Retro Recipes YouTube channel chimes with me. It follows host Perfractic and his attempts at downgrading to a ‘dumbphone’ for use when he’s out and about on dog walks and family meals. Getting away from notifications and addictive browsing habits appeals in such situations, but the challenge was to retain the ability to use Apple’s iMessage, which I too would find difficult to drop.

Since Apple doesn’t sell ‘dumbphones’, it means using a device with a different operating system. He manages it in the end but not without working through the struggle of several dead-ends, which he documents one-by-one. It’s almost not worth it given that most including me would also need to take a dedicated camera out with them. However, through the middle of the journey, he found a decent iPhone dumbing solution called Brick.

The way Brick works is by tapping the iPhone on the small Brick device, which here is located on Perfractic’s fridge door, this blocks access to all attention-grabbing apps and incoming notifications until you’re able to tap the phone on the device once again. So, tap the phone before going out—dumbphone— then tap when you return home—iPhone.

items.title: Recongestants
items.content_html:
The lesser-known downsides of having high blood pressure—let’s call them first-world problems—include not being able to take Ibuprofen (for those on certain types of hypertension control medications) and not being able to take any decent nasal decongestants. ‘Decent’ meaning ones that actually work. Hardcore Sudafed is out of the window (because of Pseudoephedrine). What you are left with are more traditional methods such as menthol sticks and a steam. You can put essential oils in the hot water to aid the efficacy of a steam, but getting the dosage right is fraught with sharp but momentary discomfort. Put too much Peppermint Oil, or even worse, Olbas Oil in there, and I honestly don’t think there’d be much difference than shoving a lit match up your nose. Think Mia Wallace at the moment she snorts the wrong powder.

My local pharmacist recommended a product called Sterimar Congestion Relief, which I didn’t question and purchased on the spot. The can is proud to say that it’s ‘FREE FROM steroids [and] drugs’, which didn’t leave me with much hope, but nevertheless safe for hypertensionists (?). Essentially, it’s purified seawater that you squirt up the nasal passages. Slightly more effective than blowing your nose dry, but the effect lasts for a few minutes before the blockage returns. Not great then. Prevention, therefore, is the best form of defence here. Now where did I put the leftover PPE?

items.title: A young person’s laundry load > than yours
items.content_html:
We have a tiny utility room at home with enough room for a washer dryer, hoover, mop, brush, basic tools, wellies and a gas boiler. I say ‘room’, a more accurate description would be a cupboard or a closet. What space remains can be filled with a dehumidifier and a clothes maiden. This is what we’ve used to dry clothes mainly for the last two years. Originally a stop-gap for autumn–winter until clothes could be hung outside on the line, this past summer was such a washout that the dehumidifier has been on for the vast majority of days during 2023.

In case of emergency or dire washing basket overload, the utility can squeeze two maidens in if the hoover and wellies come out. Since returning from Ibiza last Saturday evening, the two maiden setup has been working overtime—well, the washer dryer and dehumidifier have—to get through all the worn and crumpled holiday clothes. Judging by the dried piles, I’d say a good 70% of items belong to my 4-year-old daughter. Good going considering two adults went as well.

Take note.

The idea is simple: strap as much physical storage media [3TB] on a bird as you possibly can… Using my new Pigeon Data Transfer Equation, I can estimate a pigeon would win under its own power out to about 500 miles (800 km).

55% packet loss isn’t all that great.

items.title: Alien’s most harrowing [cut] scene
items.content_html:
The cocooning scene from Alien, cut from the original release, is possibly the most harrowing scene [not] in the film. It was supposed to feature towards the end of the movie, when Ripley is already the last remaining crew member alive, or at least we’re led to assume. This cut scene follows a flame-thrower toting Ripley into the Alien’s hive. Here, she finds crew members Dallas and Brett either metamorphosing into or being consumed by an enclosing egg. Dallas is barely alive enough to plead to Ripley to kill him, which she is reluctant to do but ultimately obliges.

The Youtube channel Alien Theory has published a deep dive into the scene including the various explanations for why the scene was cut, not least pacing. But had it remained, would it have swayed James Cameron away from introducing a queen and drones concept in the sequel Aliens?

items.title: Golden point goonage
items.content_html:
I wouldn’t say I’m particularly for overtime or golden point deciders—a draw is okay, right? But if only you could bottle the feeling when your teams win by one. Salford needed to defeat Warrington today to keep their hopes of reaching the play-offs alive, and both sides were clearly nervy.

Mark Sneyd scored his 2000th Super League point by kicking a penalty to make it 20–20 at full-time. He also had the chance to win the match in golden point extra time with his 2001st but struck the left upright with a drop goal attempt. Instead, Salford opted to go for a try down the left-hand side, which worked a treat. Cue flailing limbs and a half-hearted attempt at a pitch invasion.

Salford are at Hull KR next Saturday for another do or die showdown.

items.title: Hatch, Manchester
items.content_html:
Earlier this week I came across a modernist illustration by Bo Lundberg of Hatch with the Mancunian Way in the background. A shipping container-style market of independent eateries, coffee shops, bars, breweries, clothes shops, florists etc, I’ve spent a few days and nights out there through work lunches and after work socials.

It’s a shame then that Hatch is closing soon after 6 years at short notice (September 30th), the land sold/leased to a company (Stack) who plans a similar operation but without any guarantees to the current tenants or permanent staff of continuation or redeployment. The *MEN *reports that these people have only a month’s notice find new premises or new jobs, though they will receive priority during recruitment, there are no certainties. Sacha Lord has offered all those affected at Hatch a job at the Warehouse Project when it returns for its new season.

items.title: We (possibly) don’t need another Twitter
items.content_html:
Cal Newport blogs that we don’t need another Twitter. I suppose he would say that not being a fan of attention-sapping devices. While Twitter became too big to be a nice, sane, twee, ‘global conversation platform’—and I generally agree that in the broadest sense Twitter had long been a home for toxic babble—there are use cases for good that may be left unfulfilled if the Twitter we knew ceases to be. For example, academic Twitter.

Mark Carrigan asks where academics will turn:

My broader concern is that universities are still pushing… that every upwardly mobile ambitious academic needs to be highly visible on the dominant platform and be seen engaging on a regular basis. That was always bad advice, and, now, it is becoming counterproductive and, in some cases, dangerous, advice…

Twitter facilitated a social infrastructure for academic life in which a limited few with a big social media footprint were able to leverage it to advantage in their academic career, with greater visibility for their publications, a wide network and lots of opportunities. As that breaks down, our academic communities need to get much better at facilitating other modes of engagement so that we are never again so reliant on a big corporate platform…

I’m increasingly convinced there isn’t going to be one single Twitter alternative because the marketplace of Twitter alternatives is so crowded. For an individual academic, the key is to experiment with a platform to get a sense of whether it works…

Gina Sipley argues that even if Twitter manages to stabilise and maintain the trust of academics it will still block one the main benefits—leveraging their biggest audience, lurkers:

Lurking is a lucrative form of social media participation for platforms, if the lurker is logged in and the micrometrics of their reading history can be tracked. Content creators and influencers want their tweets to be seen by the largest possible audience; putting restrictions on lurking benefits the platform, not the creator…

Twitter Blue subscribers have access to a reader mode, which declutters the reading experience by displaying fewer ads. By enhancing the reading experience one can more leisurely lurk. However, the cost of subscribing to Twitter Blue reinforces the privileged position of the lurker. Without a subscription to Twitter Blue, lurking is a less enjoyable experience… but its price has jumped to $8 per month. This is a prohibitive price point for academics, many of whom are underemployed…

Without a Twitter Blue subscription, a current Twitter account holder could only read 600 posts per day; a new Twitter account holder could only read 300. That number has recently been lifted to 1,000 posts for current account holders, but a limit of any kind creates a geography of exclusion to lurking. Attempting to read more than the daily allotted posts, will result in a locked account. Although Musk asserts that the restrictions are temporary, no end date has yet to be announced.

Further, TweetDeck, a tool that made it easy to manage and read the tweets of multiple accounts, is no longer a free service and can only be accessed through what is now called X-premium. Twitter’s API library is also no longer open access… The current monthly cost of being a professional lurker: $1,000–$42,000.

Twitter and Facebook also became the first port of call for finding out what was happening right now on a particular topic. Whether that was globally on a breaking news story or hyper-locally to see why those fireworks were going off at 9.50pm on a Tuesday night in September. Today, whether by design or lack of resource, search on both platforms is borked to such a degree that it’s close to useless. Hashtags for following topics, conferences and such still work but the participants and the audience is fracturing.

In terms of getting the message out there, there is something to be said for large platforms that dominate their market. For example, twenty years ago, if you lived in Greater Manchester and wanted a new job, you would buy Thursday’s Manchester Evening News. It was the outlet for advertising and finding job vacancies. The search engines and web aggregators of today are plenty but aren’t as useful, taking up more time and energy to sifter. Similarly, Twitter was the every person’s PR outlet.

So, where to turn? Facebook is too personal. Instagram and TikTok don’t work in the same way; few can record and cut a hot take in one minute, never mind wanting to watch one. Some have turned to Linkedin, but the live element doesn’t really work there either. There is also an inauthenticity to using LinkedIn where we are projections of our crafted, professional image rather than our real selves. Whatsapp groups and conversations may be an outlet for the live discussion, say at a conference for example, but it’s hardly open.

Meta’s Threads appears to have legs. Although it’s intrinsically linked to Instagram, people seem to like the way it’s going for its more ephemeral, fun nature. Like the early days of Twitter, perhaps. But unlike the early days of Twitter, it does not have a text search function (yet) and does not have an API allowing for third-party clients (yet) like Tweetbot and Twitterific way back when. There are also the usual Meta issues with data collection, oh and those terms and conditions, which most will let slide if Threads hangs around for the long term. Although beyond grabbing market share from Twitter or even hobbling Musk’s X to the extent that it never bounces back, will Meta keep Threads as an ongoing concern, particularly if they can’t monetise it? Will Threads become so big that it inevitably morphs into a more derided, toxic, pre-Musk Twitter? And if you feel this may happen, is it worth investing time into building a profile on there?

Bluesky and Mastodon are in the peloton for taking the bluebird’s jersey. Bluesky is dragging its feet a little though may be playing the long game. Mastodon is arguably best placed to be what Twitter was when it was good. Decentralised and open source, Mastodon offers the promise to be whatever you want it to be. Sadly, the infrastructure for Mastodon around instances—all of which have their own ownerships, hosting bills and posting rules—will be confusing to many, and the user experience for finding people and content from those you don’t follow just isn’t there yet, and may never be because of that infrastructure. If you join a niche instance and post on there as you have been doing on Twitter, you may get short shrift from that instance’s administrator. Perhaps you didn’t refer to the correct source, or what you have posted is too much like self-promotion to the extent that it breaks those rules. Mastodon is not yet built for, and may never be for the mass.

That said, Mastodon is my current fave. As it utilises the decentralised protocol ActivityPub, it offers a route towards services that cover most of the aspects that made old Twitter good; that aggregate content from wherever it is published—whether from websites, blogs, or social networks—that are also platform agnostic, thus negating that need for big corporate platforms. This might, possibly, be why we don’t need another Twitter. Though it’s arguably closer to a pipe dream than a reality. Anyone for RSS?

items.content_html:
Keith Houston has published a ‘calculator of the day’ for a week or so now in promotion of his new book, Em­pire of the Sum: The Rise and Reign of the Pocket Cal­cu­lator. This particular one is a belter and very much a sign of the times: the 1981 Ca­sio QL-10 Cal­cu­lighter. That’s right, a calculator with a cigarette lighter built-in. Old school cool if totally impractical and archaic by 21st century standards.

📷 CC BY-SA 2.0 by Vicente Zorilla Palau.

Keith makes an interesting point about this model and Casio:

Had this been any other cal­cu­lator com­pany, it would be have been en­tirely pos­sible to de­ride the QL-10 as ’80s ex­cess gone mad. But Ca­sio alone could claim method in its mad­ness, be­cause it had got star­ted not with elec­tronic in­stru­ments, as had Hew­lett-Pack­ard; nor with geo­phys­ical sur­vey­ing equip­ment, like Texas In­stru­ments; nor cam­eras, like Canon; but rather, with the humble yu­biwa ci­gar­ette holder. For Ca­sio, the QL-10 was a home­com­ing.

Rather it has been revived into the zeitgeist by ‘surfers’ posting their adventures on TikTok.

items.content_html:
W. David Marx asks: ‘In the mid-1970s, the Sex Pistols only took two years to move up from squalid London squats to the top of the British pop charts. Why hasn’t a decade been enough time for DIY online video creators to turn their view counts into mainstream stardom?’

Marx posits a number of conclusions as to why few if any social media sensations can be called mainstream celebrities. I’m not entirely sold on them, but what he says here rings true and remains a conundrum:

We’re now at least 15 years into the dominance of online video within youth culture. In the early 2010s, surveys started to find that teenagers were much more interested in YouTube creators than legacy media stars. At the time, it seemed plausible that youth would carry these preferences into their 20s and elevate their favorite creators. That didn’t happen.

The acid test: could the names of social media’s most watched replace those in Madonna’s ‘Vogue’ and echo through the decades?

items.title: Glastonbury is the size of Manchester City Centre
items.content_html:
The hot weather continues. Perhaps not for much longer as we’re a week away from Glastonbury. Manchester Confidential posted a tweet this week with a map of the city centre overlaid with the boundary of Glastonbury site, which almost blankets it. My money would have been on Glastonbury being much bigger, only on a hunch; I’ve never been.

Another interesting article on Manchester Confidential looked at Manchester City—it’s very much their week—and their previous ground but one: Hyde Road. City (and under their previous moniker of Ardwick AFC) played at the Hyde Road ground from 1887 to 1923. The perimeter was so close to a rail track that as the stadium swelled over time with more enclosures added, the club had no choice but to place one of their stands in a corner behind the track.

Bizarrely then, the railway went through the ground. Not only that, but on occasion, trains got on the way of the action!

‘They used to take the industrial boilers out of the boiler works on the line and I’ve stories of boilers getting stuck at half time and the people in the Boys Stand (the one on t’other side of the tracks) getting somewhat frustrated.’ — Dr Gary James

It being City’s week, during my walk to Victoria Station, I took a photo of a large Nike advert on the side of Manchester’s Arndale Centre, on the corner where Tim Hortons is (and Jessops before that, and that’s as far back as I’m going). The advert featured Erling Braut Haaland, pointing out that he has won the treble, as the Premier League’s top scorer and its Player of the Year, and the golden boot (or rather the European Golden Shoe). Not a bad first season in England.

Enough talk of Manchester City, but sticking with sport, The Ashes started today. A glorious first day’s play by all accounts at Edgbaston, although I mainly listened to it on Test Match Special between meetings. The Economist published an infographic showing that if England win the series, they will become the number one ranked test side on ELO ranking for the first time since the late 1970s, and it’ll be England’s highest amount of ELO points since 1960 at least. Way to cry in a crushing defeat. ;-)

items.title: The Terroir
items.content_html:
The hot and dry weather has continued since my daughter’s birthday party last Saturday, bar a downpour of Biblical proportions on Monday that tried to put a damper on Manchester City’s treble-winning parade in the city centre. Though as Pep Guardiola remarked, it wouldn’t be a proper Mancunian celebration without rain.

In such sweltering conditions it’s hard not to think, nay fantasise about drinking a cold beer or cider, and cooling your brow with the glass. Steve Dunkley published a brilliant article this week on the concept of terroir in beer. While his label Beer Nouveau maybe on hiatus, Steve continues to write pieces for the website. Terroir is, as Steve puts it, described as the ‘the soul of the land’ and is generally a term used in winemaking:

Everything grown on that land [is] influenced by the land, and that influence [comes] through in the final glass.

Recently, Steve went to a Manchester Cider Club tasting session where the Little Pomona cidery in Herefordshire showcased seven ciders, all made from Dabinett apples, with each cider made using apples from a different orchard. While each cider had the same ingredients, each cider had subtle differences in flavour. The apples having taken on the characteristics of the land where the trees were grown. The ‘soul of the orchards’.

The ingredients for wine and cider are similar being there are few and the provenance of the main ingredient responsible for taste can be guaranteed. Less can be said for beer, apart from say hops. Steve found as much during his in the Manchester Hop Project:

We [were] able to identify a distinct flavour to our regions, all the hops grown in Manchester for instance impart a slight hazelnut flavour to the beer regardless of the hop variety. That is the terroir of Manchester, a bit nutty.

The article also includes a few more French sayings, one of which I was previously unaware: l’esprit d’escalier – a situation of thinking of the perfect reply to someone as we’re leaving and it’s too late to use that witty comeback.’ Which immediately made me think of the ‘jerk store’ episode of Seinfeld.

Steve Dunkley is also keeping a record of brewery closures in 2023 as he did for 2022. It’s grim but not unexpected.
